Due to the increasing concentration of carbon dioxide (CO2) in the atmosphere, the conversion of CO2 into usable products is particularly important. The electrochemical reduction reaction of CO2 (CO2RR) has got great attentions on single-atom catalysts (SACs) and single-cluster catalysts (SCCs) in recent years. In general, graphene is widely applied in CO2RR because of its excellent stability, predominant electrical conductivity and favorable electrochemical properties. In this review, we have summarized the electrochemical CO2RR by various graphene SACs/SCCs such as nitrogen-doped graphene, defect graphene, defect modified graphene and carbon nanotubes. Additionally, the reaction mechanisms for CO2RR and the pathways to diverse products are discussed in details. Finally, the potential opportunities and prospects of utilizing graphene SACs/SCCs for CO2RR are presented. Graphical abstract We have summarized the electrochemical CO2RR by various graphene SACs/SCCs such as nitrogen-doped graphene, defect modified graphene, defect graphene and carbon nanotubes. Additionally, the reaction mechanisms for CO2RR and the pathways to diverse products are discussed in details. Finally, the potential opportunities and prospects of utilizing graphene SACs/SCCs for CO2RR are presented. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Electrochemical Graphene CO2 reduction reaction Single-atom catalysts Single-cluster catalysts Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The severity of global warming and the current state of the environment necessitate the exploration of electrochemical carbon dioxide reduction reactions (CO2RR). As previous academic work has pointed out, these reactions have the potential to produce advanced carbon-based fuels and feedstocks [1-12]. Nevertheless, it is worth noting that the CO2 molecule exhibits a significant degree of stability. Consequently, in order to surmount the sluggish reaction kinetics associated with CO2, substantial overpotential and considerable amount of energy input are required [13]. Fortunately, the application of electrochemistry can be employed to decrease the overpotential and expedite the CO2RR at a significantly enhanced rate [14]. However, the structure and surface properties of electrochemical agents need to be engineered to improve their selectivity and maintain a corresponding level of catalytic activity. The careful choices of appropriate substrates which facilitates subsequent modifications to the structure and surface properties are helpful to obtain electrochemical CO2RR catalysts exhibiting superior performance [15-17]. In recent times, graphene has garnered significant attentions as a compelling material owing to its remarkable characteristics such as expansive surface area, elevated carrier mobility, superior thermal conductivity, and notable electrical and thermal conductivities [18,19]. Graphene has been employed as a substrate for electrochemical CO2RR in numerous research studies [20-23]. For instance, employing metal as the structural basis and incorporating graphene as a constituent, by modified/functionalized to incorporate anchoring sites (e.g., oxygen functionalities and unsaturated N atoms) to stabilize the metallic centers. Functions embedded in the pristine graphene lattice can serve as catalytic sites for CO2RR or as complexation sites for immobilizing active metal electrocatalysts with different morphologies and structures (e.g., particles, clusters, dimers, and single atoms) [24-27]. The primary factor contributing to this phenomenon is the limited capacity of pristine graphene to reduce CO2, primarily attributed to the presence of neutral carbon atoms within a metal framework. Consequently, it becomes crucial to fabricate metal SACs/SCCs which integrate both metal framework and graphene. Graphene-load metal SACs have been demonstrated to own notable benefits in terms of their activity and selectivity by previous studies [28-36]. In comparison to single atom catalysts, it has been observed that metal single-cluster catalysts with graphene as support exhibit enhanced tunability and stability in terms of electronic structure and geometry [37-41]. Numerous theoretical and experimental investigations have demonstrated that the introduction of heteroatoms such as boron, nitrogen, phosphorus, and so on into graphene can induce significant modifications in its electronic characteristics and chemical reactivity. These modifications can lead to the emergence of novel functionalities, thereby enhance the catalytic efficiency for CO2 reduction [42-44]. In this paper, we have summarized the mechanism of CO2RR and analyzed the possible intermediates including *CO2, *OCHO, *COOH, *CO or other possible products. Subsequently, we focused on graphene load metal SACs for CO2 reduction, which were divided into N-doped graphene load metal SACs, defect graphene SACs and defect modified graphene SACs. Meanwhile, the reaction pathways and products of CO2 conversion were analyzed by N-doped graphene SACs, defect graphene SACs and defect modified graphene SACs were load with different transition metals for CO2RR. For N-doped graphene, Fe, Ni, Zn and Ru metals are mainly analyzed in the production with the energy required and reaction efficiency to elucidate the reaction mechanism of CO2RR. Meanwhile, in addition to CO2RR on graphene metal SACs, innovative modifications that adjust the structure of defective graphene while loading Pt metal SACs are also discussed, aiming to improve the reduction efficiency of CO2. Due to the diverse structures and coordination of SACs in various environments, systematic exploration of CO2RR on SACs is limited. Thus, graphene SCCs in the form of connected carbon nanotubes (CNTs) have also been generally discussed, which exhibit excellent catalytic performance of CO2RR, opening up new research opportunities in atomic level. Finally, the future of graphene load SACs/SCCs is broadly analyzed and outlook (Fig. 1 ). 2 CO2 reduction 2.1 Principles of CO2 electrolysis The study conducted by Sun et al. [45] determined that the electrochemical reduction of CO2 takes place at the interface between the electrode and the electrolyte. This process involves the formation of carbon bonds and the breaking of CO bonds through the transfer of protons and electrons. Additionally, CO2 is absorbed onto the catalyst's surface, followed by the desorption and formation of new products on the electrode. Finally, the products are allowed to diffuse from the electrode's surface into the electrolyte. In addition, Hasani et al. [1] have reached the conclusion that the fundamental aspects affecting CO2RR electrolysis are as follows: Current density, Overpotential, Onset potential, Tafel slope, and Faradaic efficiency. Ma et al. [18] has found that electrochemical CO2 reduction can be carried out by many kinds of reactions in which a number of electrons were transferred. Depending on the different transfer numbers of electron and proton, the conversion of CO2 can form various compounds such as HCOOH, H2C2O4, CO, CH2O, CH3OH, CH4, C2H4, C2H5OH, C2H4O2, C2H6, C3H4O2, C3H7OH, and C4H4O3. These conversions are represented by Eqs. (1)-(12). The reduction potentials for the standard hydrogen electrode (SHE) are measured at pH 0, 1.0 atm, and 25 °C [46]. The hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) is a reduction process involving the transfer of two electrons (Eq. (13)), which competes with other reactions. Simultaneously, the process of CO2 reduction necessitates a nucleophilic assault on the C atom, resulting in the distortion of the O=C=O bond. The initial stage in the direct electrochemical reduction of CO2 involving the creation of radical anions (CO2 ‒) through a single electron transfer process (Eq. (14)). Additionally, this process necessitates a highly negative equilibrium potential. Therefore, a large number of experimental and theoretical results are needed to support a more comprehensive understanding of the mechanism of CO2 reduction. Dattila et al. [47] explored the formation of C1 and C2+ products along with a range of potential intermediates in the electrochemical CO2RR (Fig. 2 ). The CO2 reduction pathway to produce C1, C2+ products and the mechanism of the HER were depicted in Fig. 2a, b and c respectively. 2.2.1 CO2 radical anion (CO2 ‒) The electrochemical CO2RR process begins with the transfer of electrons into CO2 to generate CO2 ‒ [46]. However, in order to reorganize the linear molecule into a bent radical anion, a significant amount of energy must be input at this step. Nevertheless, *CO2 ‒ has a very brief lifetime in both aqueous and non-aqueous solutions. For this reason, scientists have explored microscopic and spectroscopic methods such as scanning electrochemical microscopy (SECM). SECM consists of three main components: (1) A motion control system that moves the SECM tip electrode. (2) A constant potentiostat monitoring the SECM tip current. (3) Software that connects the constant potentiostat to the motion control system [48]. Based on this, Kai et al. [49] studied CO2 ‒ with two distinct SECMs. Oxalic acid oxidation was carried out using a Pt nano-electrode as an SECM generator, and the produced intermediates were collected using a Pt ultramicro electrode as an SECM collector. The substrate was found to primarily trap CO2 ‒ species with the range of gap distance d between 73 nm and 500 nm, in which range CO2 ‒ is observable. Furthermore, CO2 ‒ in a dimethyl formamide-based electrolyte at a hemispherical mercury/platinum electrode were measured using SECM on a mercury/gold electrode. Between the substrate and the nanogap of the SECM tip, the produced CO2 ‒ can be observed to form oxalate. Additionally, a number of spectroscopy-based techniques, including Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy and Raman spectroscopy, have been used to investigate the detection of common intermediates at metal electrode interfaces [50-52]. 2.2.2 Formation of *OCHO, *COOH and *CO *OCHO is considered to be an intermediate product accompanying the production of CO, methane, and HCOOH. Yoo et al. [53] has found that *OCHO was formed by two routes and was originated from proton-coupled electron transfer (CO2 + e– + H+ → *OCHO). Additionally, a mechanism was proposed for the *OCHO transferred from hydride (CO2 + *H → *OCHO) by Cheng [54]. According to the study of Peterson et al. [55], *COOH can facilitate the synergistic transfer of electrons and protons to generate CO (*COOH + e– + H+ → CO +H2O). With theoretical calculations, Chai et al. [56] discovered that *COOH formation on N-doped graphene was preferable than *OCHO. *CO is a potential intermediate accompanying with some C2+ products (two or more carbon atoms, such as C2H4, C2H6, C2H5OH, C2H4O, C2H4O2, C2H6O2, and C3H7OH) and C1 products (CO, HCHO, CH4, and CH3OH) [57]. Kortlever et al. [58] found that pairwise electron transfer was primarily responsible for the electrochemical conversion of CO2 to CO. Furthermore, Sun et al. [45] studied the process of CO2 reduction and found CO and H2O can be produced through the OH group of *COOH. However, the conversion of CO2 to *COOH may be hampered by the limiting rate of CO2 reduction which may occur during this process. Noble metal catalysts such as Pd, Ag, Au, Zn and so forth are proved to be helpful to create *CO intermediates and desorb from metal electrodes to form CO due to weak binding of *CO [44,55,59,60]. 2.2.3 Formation of CH4, CH3OH, and CH2O According to density functional theory (DFT) calculations done on Cu (211), Peterson et al. [55] found that Cu surface was thermodynamically favorable for the formation of *CO intermediates, which may be successively converted into *HCO, *H2CO (desorb as HCHO) and *H3CO with continuous hydrogenation. CH3OH will be produced with further reduction of *H3CO. Moreover, CH4 is generated from CHO intermediate with the entire pathway of CO2 → COOH → CO → CHO → CH2O → CH3O → CH4 + O → CH4 + OH → CH4 + H2O (leaving H+ + e− reactants and the first water product formed). In the meantime, Nie et al. [61] have CO to COH, eventually leading to CHx species and the ability to produce both CH4 and CH3OH. This path does not occur during the nonelectrochemical CH3OH synthesis from syngas. Simultaneous proposed pathways are able to reconcile data on CO2, CO and CH2O reduction at Cu electrodes. Using the above DFT calculations, the reduction of CO was identified as the key selectivity-determining step for the electroreduction of CO2 on Cu (111), discovered that the main products of CO reduction are CH4 and CH3OH. 2.2.4 Formation of C2+ products Major pathways to generate C2+ products are usually associated with *C2O2 − intermediate which plays a key role in CC bond making [58]. *C2O2 − intermediates are generated from CO dimerization mediated by electron transfer [62,63]. Then, proton transfer happens after the formation of the negatively charged adsorbed CO dimer. This is why the carbon monoxide reduction reaction favors alkaline media. At the same time, Zhao et al. [64] also found two possible reaction pathways for the C2+ products. One is that *OCCOH, which is formed when two *CO connect to each other after being protonated, forms *OCHCH2 with further protonation. By removing the O bonded to the active site and subsequently repeating the hydrogenation reaction on C, this intermediate can be used to generate C2H4 or C2H6O. In the other pathway, *OCCH3 is produced by two C atoms simultaneously attached to the active site and hydrogenated on the C away from O after *OCCOH removes the water molecule. 3 Graphene load metal single-atom catalysts for CO2RR Graphene and its derivatives are frequently utilized as essential ingredients in the creation of CO2RR electrocatalysts due to their distinctive surface characteristics, large surface area, outstanding stability, and excellent conductivity [65,66]. However, graphene must first be functionalized or altered to add anchor sites (such as unsaturated N atoms and oxygen functions) in order to stabilize the metal center before it can be utilized to create metal-based electrocatalysts [25-27]. This section describes graphene load metal single-atom electrocatalysts for CO2RR, including the load of different metal single atoms and the presentation of nitrogen-doped graphene versus defect graphene structures. The recent development of graphene load metal SACs for the electrochemical reduction of CO2 are summarized in Table 1 . Among these data, we selected several catalysts to describe in detail later. 3.1 Nitrogen-doped graphene load metal single-atom catalysts 3.1.1 Nitrogen-doped graphene substrates Metal SACs are usually immobilized on doped graphene, where the metal species and bound heteroatoms complex to stabilize the metal SACs. The heteroatom N is frequently utilized for doped graphene due to its high electronegativity (N 3.04, C 2.55) and similar atomic size to C. The higher electronegativity of N redistributes the charge between N and neighboring C, giving positive charge and high spin density to CO2RR catalytic activity. In addition, the faintly acid promotes CO2 adsorption to the Lewis base N sites to expedite CO2RR [79]. N-doped graphene (NG) [80], NG single-layer [81], NG oxide, and NG quantum dots are typical examples of commonly doped graphene [14,43,82]. Although these can all work in concert to promote metal SACs for CO2RR, NG is our main focus here. Regarding the fabrication of NG, there are usually two approaches: top-down (Fig. 3a ) and bottom-up (Fig. 3b) [83,84]. Unlike the conventional method, Xia et al. [85] functionalized with amine groups (GQDs–NH2) and mixed with transition metal salts in solutions, GQDs can stably and uniformly spread and confine transition metal cations on their surfaces (Fig. 3c) due to the strong chelation/complexation effect between metal cations and amine groups [86]. This strong interaction helped the quantum dots to interconnect with each other and self-assemble into a layered bulk structure during the freeze-drying process of the Ir3+/GQDs–NH2 mixture [87]. After the pyrolysis process in an ammonia-rich atmosphere, a dense infrared single-atom catalyst can be obtained. Which is currently the most widely used method for the metal centered single-atoms used to stabilize transition metal [88-90], and starting from surface-functionalized graphene quantum dots (GQDs) (Fig. 3c). Some NG catalysts composed of commonly transition metal single-atoms for electrochemical reduction of CO2 are given as follow. 3.1.2 Ni N G catalyst for CO2RR The electrochemical reduction of CO2 using monatomic catalysts is a promising approach for the study of excess renewable electricity from fuels. In recent years, Ni NG catalysts have attracted particular attention and have been proposed as industrially efficient catalysts for the exclusive production of CO from CO2RR [91]. For instance, Yang et al. [92] looked into the reaction principle of transition metal-nitrogen-carbon (Fe, Co, Ni) SACs for the selection of Ni atoms. In this case, the number of doped nitrogen atoms for Ni was four, and the doping types were pyridinic-N4. Ni atoms are supported on NG (Ni-N4@Gr) (Fig. 4a ). The d-band center of Ni-N4@Gr is lower, indicating a weak interaction between the metal site and the intermediate, according to a comparison of the density of states of Ni-N4@Gr between the metal atoms and the N atoms projected in the d orbitals that was computed (Fig. 4b). Following a thorough examination of the pathways leading to the production of different products, including CO, HCHO, HCOOH, CH3OH, and CH4, as well as the optimal hydrogenation pathway structure at a potential of 0 V, the corresponding structures of various states of Ni-N4@Gr and the corresponding free energy changes (Fig. 4c) were obtained for the CO2 reduction catalytic cycling process (Fig. 4d). The intermediates involved in CO2 reduction by Ni-N4@Gr catalyst encompass *OCHO, *CO, *CHO, *CH2O, *CH2OH. Concurrently, the potential products of CO2 conversion comprise HCOOH, CH3OH and CH4. Notably, it was observed that the Ni-N4@Gr exhibited preference for generating HCOOH during CO2RR. For the reduction of CO2 by Ni NG, the CO2RR activity of Ni NG catalyst was further enhanced using a variety of unique strategies, including modification of morphology and pore structure, tuning the coordination structure of metal centers and local environment [94-98]. For example, ligand-unsaturated Ni-Nx sites such as Ni-N3, Ni-N3V (V is the ligand vacancy in the center of Ni) and Ni-N2V2 exhibit higher CO2RR than Ni-N4 sites activity and selectivity [95,98,99]. Accordingly, Boppella et al. [93] analyzed N sites in Ni-N4 based on Ni-N4 graphene catalyst studies. Considered the coordination of four pyrrole N atoms (Ni-N4) in NG after developing a soft template-assisted technique and synthesizing pyrrole N4-Ni sites with various N-type defects. In addition, the use of Ni-doped N-free models in DFT graphene calculations is considered (Fig. 4e). The excellent COOH* kinetics on pyrrolic N are illustrated side by side by Fig. 4f, which shows the free energies of COOH* intermediates on graphite N and pyridine nitrogen, which are 2.57 eV and 0.30 eV, respectively, higher than that of pyrrolic N (−0.40 eV). In the meantime, because of the strong binding of CO*, the pyrrolic N sites must overcome high desorption free energy during CO* desorption. This suggested that the slow desorption of CO* or the difficulty of COOH* formation limited the catalytic performance of the N-doped sites for CO2RR. Following that, Fig. 4g analysis of the free energy change for the generation of COOH* at the Ni-N4-Ni site (0.66 eV) revealed that it was lower than at the Ni-N4-N site (0.69 eV), suggesting that the Ni atom is the CO2RR active site [100]. At the same time the Fig. 4h shows that the free energy pathway for the desorption of CO* on the surface of Ni-N4-N (0.38 eV) is thermodynamically more favorable than that from the surface of Ni-N4-Ni (0.07 eV), despite the fact that Ni-N4-Ni binds COOH* more strongly than Ni-N4-N. This suggests that pyrrolidone facilitates the desorption of CO on the Ni-N4 site. In conclusion, both the reducing activity of CO2 and the free energy characteristics of the reaction intermediates are significantly influenced by the pyrrolic group. On the basis of the Ni NG catalyst that has been studied, Ni2+on NG (Ni2+@NG) was investigated by Bi et al. [71], it is concluded that Ni2+@NG is superior to NG because it allows for the highly selective electrochemical reduction of CO2 to CO (Fig. 5a ). The specific basis for this is shown in Fig. 5b and Fig. 5c, showing the free energy maps of Ni2+@NG with NG obtained by electrochemistry for CO2RR with hydrogen evolution reaction (HEL free energy) that are also mentioned. Based on these, it is intuitively clear that Ni2+@NG is clearly the less energy-consuming and faster-reacting party in the conversion of CO2 to CO, as well as the weaker bound party to H +in the HER process. Additionally, it was determined that when *COOH is protonated to form adsorbed *CO, NG with a quadruple pyridine configuration has a higher free energy barrier than NG. It's also noteworthy that, in contrast to N-doped graphene, the free energy diagram of HER demonstrates that *H likewise exhibits a strong adsorption on N-doped graphene. When compared to N-doped graphene, Ni2+@NG shows more active UL (CO2)-UL (H2) (Fig. 5d). It can be concluded from DFT analysis that Ni2+@NG is superior to NG for CO2 reduction. Although a large number of structure-property related studies have been carried out for the development of Ni NG catalysts, there are conflicting and completely opposite views on the influence of the Ni coordination environment on their catalytic performance. In addition, there is still a lack of a complete and systematic study of all possible structures, especially on the effect of vacancy defects and comparison of structures with and without vacancy defects overall. The catalytic performance of Ni NG catalysts is strongly influenced by complex terms such as the number of N ligands, carrier characteristics, and so on. The appropriate number of N coordination sites plays a more important role in each of the terms [102-104]. Consequently, An et al. [101] looked into and analyzed how many N atoms were coordinated to Ni atoms in Ni graphene SACs. Based on this information, seven distinct conformations were created and divided into groups I and II (Fig. 5e and Fig. 5f), respectively. Based on this, the corresponding free energy calculations were performed for the various configurations. The Fig. 5g illustrates that, with the exception of Ni-N1, the group II catalysts exhibit higher activity levels than the group I catalysts. Better selectivity is achieved as a result of the inhibition of undesired product formation brought about by the lower free energy variation. Ultimately, it was discovered that Ni-N3-V had a low overpotential and high selectivity when it came to reducing CO2 to CO, making it a possible candidate material. 3.1.3 Zn NG catalyst for CO2RR Although a number of transition metal-nitrogen-carbon catalysts have been investigated for electrochemical reduction of CO2, the true active site for the formation of the generated CO is still controversial. In addition, there are few reports on the use of zinc ligand NG (Zn-N-G) electrocatalysts for electrochemical reduction of CO2. Based on this, Chen et al. [76] investigated Zn-N-G catalysts, which can reduce CO2 to CO via electrocatalysis. These catalysts were made as (Fig. 6a ). DFT was utilized to compute the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2. *COOH and *CO adsorption intermediates typically undergo a proton and double electron transfer process that generates CO [71,105,106]. The Zn-N4-G and N-G catalysts free energy comparison plots for the CO2RR were calculated, as shown in Fig. 6b. The addition of Zn-Nx active sites reduced the energy barrier created by the intermediates COOH* and CO*, which eventually made it easier to produce CO. Furthermore, as demonstrated by (Fig. 6c), the more negative ΔPlimit is, the lower the selectivity of CO when calculating the difference (ΔPlimit) between the limiting potentials (Plimit (CO2RR) – Plimit (HER)) for electrochemical reduction of CO2 and hydrogen precipitation reactions [71,107]. The Zn-N4-G catalyst exhibits a relatively high selectivity when used for the electrochemical reduction of CO2, as evidenced by its slightly more positive ΔPlimit. On this basis, Han et al. [108] designed a single-atom load Zn electrocatalyst on microporous NG considering more possible intermediates. Calculated by DFT (Fig. 6d), the first step is the generation of *OCHO, where the O atom binds to the Zn atom and the hydrogen binds to the carbon (Fig. 6e). By comparing the free energy barriers of *OCHO at 0.46 eV and *COOH at 1.2 eV, it was discovered that the intermediate *OCHO is more stable than the intermediate *COOH (Fig. 6d, e, f, g). At the same time the carbon-bound *COOH intermediate is essential for the production of CO, and the electrochemical reduction of CO2 to CO pathway is greatly inhibited from the very beginning [109], unlike other findings of the same type. For this reason, it was concluded by (Fig. 6f and Fig. 6g) that *OCHO is more readily formed than *COOH. Consequently, in the subsequent proton-electron transfer step, the formation of CO is impeded by the favorable *OCHO formation. Meanwhile, as shown in Fig. 6 g, it can be seen that the potential barrier for the adsorption of hydrogen is higher than that for the formation of *OCHO, and it can also be found that the main product other than H2 is CH4. In conclusion, for SACs containing Zn, the O atoms in *OCHO are more likely to form chemical bonds with Zn than C atoms during the electrochemical reduction of CO2, which prevents the generation of CO and instead favors the generation of CH4, leading to better CO2 treatment outcomes. This advances the search for reliable and effective SACs for CO2 electrochemical reduction. 3.1.4 Fe N G catalyst for CO2RR Since the research on NG catalysts has become more and more popular in recent years, for the purpose of study transition metal NG catalysts for CO2RR in a more cost-effective way, Zhang et al. [69] selected Fe atoms load on NG. In order to better understand the reaction mechanism of CO2 reduction by NG Fe (4 N atoms (Fe-N4)) SACs, the first thing to do is to prepare the catalyst. As shown in Fig. 7a , b, c, a modified Hummer method was first employed to disperse of prepared 200 mg of graphene oxide in 100 mL of deionized water [110]. An aqueous solution of (0.0125 m, 1.5 mL) of ferric chloride was added to the graphene oxide solution, and the obtained mixture was ultrasonicated through the bath, and dried by lyophilization to form a three-dimensional graphene oxide foam with uniformly distributed iron ions and a minimized graphene oxide re-stacking. Afterwards the graphene oxide foam was annealed in Ar/NH3 at high temperatures (650–800 °C) for 1 h, allowing the N-doped and graphene oxide to undergo simultaneous reduction [111]. After annealing at 750 °C (Fe/NG-750), the final Fe/NG product was obtained with an iron load of 1.25 wt%, by immobilizing iron atoms on the graphene surface through the introduction of N-doped. After that, VASP was used to run DFT simulations. Using free energy diagrams, the reaction process of CO2 conversion from *COOH intermediate to CO was studied (Fig. 7d). The CO2 molecule first adsorbs at the Fe catalytic center, where it then coordinates the transfer of electrons and protonations to form *COOH. Afterwards the generated proton-electron transfer reduction of the Fe-N4-COOH intermediate results in the formation of CO* adducts, along with the generation of an H2O molecule. The weakly bonded CO* adduct eventually breaks down to produce the main product, CO. Concurrently, the NG substrate exhibits a synergistic effect that stimulates the catalytic pathway [112-116]. Furthermore, the free energy diagrams of three distinct NG configurations must be taken into account (Fig. 7d, e, f, g). In conclusion, it is evident that the NG lowers the energy barrier for the production of COOH*, activates CO* desorption, enhances the Fe-N moiety's catalytic activity, and better enables and boosts the CO2RR efficiency. Carrying atomically dispersed nitrogen-coordinated iron sites (Fe-N4) on graphene provides a unique opportunity to convert electrochemical CO2RR to CO. However, the strong adsorption of *CO on the embedded Fe-N4 sites in intact graphene limits the current density due to the slow CO desorption process. Herein, Pan et al. [117] manipulation of graphene pore edges was investigated to simultaneously alter the local electronic structure of isolated Fe-N4 sites and enhance their intrinsic reactivity to facilitate CO production. For this purpose, three parts were constructed to represent the Fe-N4 configuration, including Fe-N4-bulk, Fe-N4-pore, and Fe-N4-edge, and density-functional theory calculations were performed. As shown in Fig. 8a , the Fe-C bond lengths on the Fe-N4-bulk, Fe-N4-pore, and Fe-N4-edge sites were 1.72, 1.77, and 1.78 Å, respectively, during the dissociation of *COOH from *CO. It is known that an increase in the Fe-C bond length weakens the *CO adsorption on the rich-edge site, the stronger the Fe-C bond interaction, the shorter the bond length. The CO2RR free energy diagrams for the three configurations are displayed in Fig. 8b. It was found that the first proton-coupled electron transfer process for the activation of CO2 to form *COOH was prompted due to its thermodynamic uphill nature. Fig. 8c illustrates the UL(CO2)-UL(H2) difference for the three configurations, and it can be seen that the UL(CO2)-UL(H2) differences of 0.23 V and 0.18 V for Fe-N4-pore and Fe-N4-edge, respectively, are greater than or approximately equal to the UL(CO2)-UL(H2) difference (0.18 V) for Fe-N4-bulk, which explains the improved CO selectivity due to the introduction of pores. The data in Fig. 8d further illustrate that the interaction between *CO and Fe-N4 is weaker at the pore-rich sites than at the non-porous sites. The d-band centers of the Fe-N4 block, Fe-N4 pore, and Fe-N4 rims are −0.92, −1.29, and −1.52 eV, respectively (Fig. 8e), indicating that the primary cause of the decrease in CO adsorption on the Fe unit site is the pore-edge-induced downward shift of the d-band center. As of now, Fig. 8f schematic diagram depicts the bond formation between CO adsorbate and Fe-N4. Furthermore, the CO2-to-CO electroreduction process is efficiently regulated and the *CO desorption process is promoted by using hole-edge engineering to crop the d-band centers of Fe-N4 atoms. The results indicate that, the construction of holes supporting Fe-N4 on the graphene substrate could significantly improve its CO2RR activity compared with the pore-deficient Fe-N4 graphene. 3.1.5 Ru N G catalyst for CO2RR It has been found that a single transition metal atom doped with four coordinating nitrogen atoms (TM-N4) in graphene plays a key role in the process of CO2RR [118,119]. Specifically, the exact location, activity and efficiency of TM-N4 have attracted much interest in theoretical and experimental studies of CO2RR [66,69,103,120-123]. For converting CO2 to CO, for instance, single-atom Ni-modified NG was prepared with a conversion frequency of 2700h−1 and a faraday efficiency of 90 % [66] by Wang et al. [124] The potential for CO2 to CH4 conversion in representative SACs in graphene (TM-N4) was also investigated by first-principles calculations. In candidate TM-N4, the low limiting potential of Ru-N4 formed by noble metal Ru was calculated to be −0.30 V. Meanwhile, the free energy of HER reduction and the limiting potential difference between CO2RR (UL(CO2)) and HER (UL(H2)) were also investigated for TM-N4 (Fig. 11a and Fig. 11b). When its limiting point difference is positive, it indicates that the CO2RR selectivity is high. The findings demonstrate that the UL(CO2)-UL(H2) value of Ru-N4 is positive. It can be concluded that the unfavorable HER of Ru-N4 ensures higher CO2RR selectivity, compared to other TMs, Ru-N4 has a higher selectivity for CH4, which is more favorable for the reduction of CO2. Although NG load Ru SACs can electrochemically reduce CO2 to CH4 with high selectivity and catalytic activity, there are still some issues to be solved [118]. Liu et al. [125] found that RuN4-doped graphene (RuN4-Gra) has strong adsorption on catalyst surface that is easily poisoned by the generated CO. In order to lessen the CO binding strength, Ru single-atom doped nitrogen oxidized graphene catalyst (RuN4/O-Gra) was fabricated (Fig. 9c and Fig. 9d). When graphene is modified, the poisoning effect of CO is avoided, and RuN4/O-Gra's catalytic activity for CO2RR is superior to that of RuN4-Gra. This is demonstrated by Fig. 9e, wherein RuN4/O-Gra oxygen atom modification results in a significantly altered pathway that is preferable to produce HCOO, which prevents the hydrogenation of COOH to CO. Furthermore, Fig. 9f demonstrates that RuN4-Gra has a stronger HER than RuN4/O-Gra, with a free energy change −0.55 eV. This demonstrates RuN4/O-Gra is more suitable than RuN4-Gra to be a CO2RR catalyst. 3.2 Defect graphene load metal single-atom catalysts 3.2.1 Defect graphene substrate Defect graphene on CO2RR activity is closely related to the structure. Graphene possesses a sp2 conjugated carbon network. The symmetric electron distribution and balanced valence make it usually not active for CO2RR. However, by removing carbon atoms from host with balanced order, structural distortions, vacancies and topological defects, as well as the presence of dangling bonds at the edges of graphene with already charge-polarized carbon atoms, have the effect of interfering with the electronic symmetry of the aromatic ring, and ultimately promote the activity of electrocatalysts during the electrocatalytic reaction [126-132]. Furthermore, certain nearby carbon atoms can be modulated by the local asymmetric redistribution of electrons caused by graphene defects [126]. However, the generation of high-density topological defects in graphene frameworks is a significant challenge due to the presence of high formation energies. Using a denitrification technique, Han et al. [133] produced topologically defect graphene. First, NG were created, and then N atoms were eliminated by a high-temperature thermal annealing treatment at 1150 °C (Fig. 10a ). Dong et al. [126] used NH3 thermal treatment to prepare defect carbon with multilayer graphene domains containing topological defects (Fig. 10b). Apart from the previously techniques, Stonee Wales defect is a unique type of defect graphene that doesn't require any atoms to be added or removed [134]. Meyer et al. [135] converted the four hexagons into two pentagons with two heptagons (SW(55–77) defect) by rotating one of the CC bonds by 90°. Additionally, the formation energy of the SW(55–77) defect is Ef = 5 eV (Fig. 10c and Fig. 10d). 3.2.2 Defect graphene load Cu atom catalyst CO2RR The two main challenges in the conversion of CO2 to other substances are the high critical potential and low selectivity of catalysts, which can be challenging to overcome. These two issues are similar in heavily rely on the electrode material [136,137]. Additionally, the TMs have a strong attraction because the band is extremely close to the Fermi energy level, which can effectively overcome intrinsic activation barriers and reaction kinetics [138,139]. Because of this, Back et al. [118] looked into graphene TM SACs with single- and double-vacancy defects, M@sv-Gr or M@dv-Gr, where M=Ag, Au, Co, Cu, Fe, Ir, Ni, Os, Pd, Pt, Rh, or Ru (Fig. 11a ). Moreover, *COOH or *OCHO on defect graphene metal SACs adsorbed well on *H, and many SACs exhibited high selectivity for CO2 reduction reactions with no competing hydrogen precipitation reactions. Among non-precious metals (such as Co, Cu, Fe, Ni), these catalysts can easily generate CH3OH or other products. Cu atoms were selected to form the defect graphene SACs because of its unique 2D material structure, which displays numerous valuable physical and chemical phenomena [140]. Among the TMs, Cu atoms were selected to create the single-atom graphene load with defects. It's not just that, altering the quantity of atomic vacancies in graphene helps to destabilize Cu, boost surface activity, and increase capacity to absorb CO2. On this foundation, Liu et al. [141] explored the mechanism of electrochemical CO2RR to CH3OH with graphene load Cu single-atom catalysts. The free energies of the CO2 reduction intermediates in the electrochemical reaction pathway were calculated using DFT and computational hydrogen electrode methods. Two different catalysts based on 3 coordinated single-copper atoms (Cu-G3) and four coordinated single-copper atoms (Cu-G4) were first created and studied. Specifically, one or two carbon atoms were removed from the graphene structure to reach a polymerized state, which led to the formation of graphene load Cu SACs super monomers. The formation of graphene load copper SACs supercell was achieved by simultaneously inserting one or two copper single-atoms into the corresponding graphene (Fig. 11b). Additionally, a thorough analysis of the CO2RR reduction pathways for the two distinct substrates was conducted. The HCOO reduction pathway over Cu-G3 catalyst is as follows, as seen in Fig. 11c: CO2→*HCOO→*HCOOH→*CHO→*CH2O→*CH3O→*CH3OH→ CH3OH(g). Additionally provided are the relative free energies for each step in the COOH pathway for CO2 reduction on the Cu-G3 catalyst surface. The COOH reduction pathway that has been identified as: CO2→*COOH→*CO→*CHO→*CH2O→ *CH3O→*CH3OH→CH3OH(g). The formate pathway, on the other hand, has a 0.41 eV free energy barrier and a more stable configuration. On the other hand, CH3OH was generated by hydrogenation over the Cu-G4 catalyst, and the detailed mechanism of the CO2RR on graphene load single copper atoms was determined together with Cu-G3. Fig. 11d illustrates the relative free energies of the steps in the HCOO pathway over the Cu-G4 catalyst. The electrochemical reduction path is as follows: CO2→*HCOO→*HCOOH→*CHO→*CH2O→*CH3O→*CH3OH→CH3OH(g). CO2 to *HCOO is the initial stage of the hydrogenation of CO2. And provides a detailed illustration of the relative free energies of each step in the COOH in Cu-G4 catalyst. Based on the electrochemical reduction free energy of CO2 results, it seems that Cu-G4 is more heavily oxidized than Cu-G3. Therefore, Cu-G3 is favored to convert CO2 to CH3OH. Comparing with Cu, Ag, Pd, and Pt under conditions employing graphene triple-coordinated metal atoms [142]. Free energies for the reduction of CO2 were calculated by He et al. (Fig. 11e). The limiting step with Ag, Pd, Pt, and Co (Fig. 12c ) metals revealed that the Cu SACs demonstrated very competitive properties in the production of CH3OH despite trailing elements in the production of CH4. Liu et al. [141] reconfirmed Cu-G3 can easily convert CO2 to CH3OH. 3.2.3 Defect graphene load Ag atom catalyst CO2RR He et al. [142] metal single-atoms dominated and supported on defect graphene have been studied as electrochemical CO2RR catalysts by means of a first-principles approach and computational hydrogen electrode modeling. A detailed analysis was conducted on the reaction pathways of five representative metals, namely Ag, Cu, Pd, Pt, and Co, with the production of different C1 products, including CO, CH2O, CH3OH, HCOOH, and CH4 (Fig. 12a). These single metal atoms are attached to the single C vacancies in graphene, which is selected as the carrier. Based on DFT calculations, it has been revealed that Ag exhibits superior performance in the reduction of CO2. Specifically, it demonstrates a higher efficacy for CH4 production compared to CH3OH. Due to a breakdown in the proportional relationship between CH3OH and OH, the affinity of Ag for OH is relatively weak comparing to high in CH3OH. As a result, the rate-limiting step in CH4 production involves the release of OH* from the surface, leading to high yield of CH4. The main process is, CO2 is first converted to CHO*(Fig. 12b), meanwhile, one of the main rate-limiting steps has previously been identified as the formation of CHO*. After that, CH4 was produced, and the rate-limiting step for the reaction's free energy was also the lowest (Fig. 12c). Fig. 12d shows the reason for the generation of superior substitutes compared to CH3OH (CH4 generation). Breaking in the proportionality between OH and CH3OH can result in a stronger bond between OH and CH3OH, this makes it easier for OH* groups to be released from the surface, thus producing CH4 and promoting the conversion of CO2. 3.2.4 Defect modified graphene load Pt nanoparticles CO2RR Modified graphene improves the adsorption of CO2 by the graphene mechanism and makes the synergistic effect between it and the electrocatalyst noble metal more pronounced. Research has identified examples such as polymerized ionic liquids, polyethyleneimine, and adenine [143-145]. For instance, Tamilarasan et al. [144] used the hydrogen exfoliation technique (HEG) to synthesize graphene for the first time. This method produced graphene with a folded structure due to the quick removal of functional groups that contained oxygen. Afterwards the graphene surface was functionalized by polymeric ionic liquids (PIL) to make it more mimetic to CO2 molecules, while the Pt nanoparticles were used as the main part of the Modified graphene Pt nanoparticles catalysts for CO2 reduction were obtained by decorating them with HEG and HEG-PIL. Where HEG transmission electron microscope (Fig. 13a ) saw that the disorder of the graphite structure led to exfoliation of the flakes and the transparency of the layers indicated that graphene was less laminated and highly wrinkled [146]. The PIL fraction, residual functional groups, and surface defects all contributed to the improved dispersion of the metal nanoparticles [147]. As shown in Fig. 13b. Ultimately, Fig. 13c shows that, following PIL functionalization, the particle distribution does not significantly change. Meanwhile, the obtained modified graphene Pt nanoparticles catalysts possessed higher formic acid formation rates compared to those catalysts with unmodified graphene carriers. The enhanced interaction between CO2 molecules and modified graphene carriers was identified as the cause of the improved performance. The use of PIL for CO2 adsorption, which aids in CO2 accumulation and boosts conversion efficiency, is what makes study novel (Fig. 13d). In addition, graphene oxide (GO) is being widely used as an improved carbon material and especially for catalysts [148,149]. GO is formed by extremely thin layers of interconnected carbon atoms with lateral dimensions of a few micrometers and a thickness of less than 1 nanometer. The hybridization angles of the carbon atoms in graphene oxide are 90° and 120°, respectively, which contain oxygen functional groups such as epoxy, hydroxyl, carbon and carboxyl groups [150]. By reducing graphene oxide and changing it to reduced graphene oxide (rGO) and altering its oxygen content, its chemical properties are improved for specific purposes such as CO2 reduction. Therefore, considering the incredible properties of rGO and the selective effect of heterocyclic compounds on CO2 reduction, their synergistic function can be exploited by assembling heterocyclic compounds on rGO. Zarandi et al. [151] created a unique electrocatalyst for the electrochemical conversion of CO2 to CH4. i.e.: platinum nanoparticles on histamine-rGO plates (Pt@His-rGO) supported by glassy carbon (GC) support (Fig. 13e). The cyclic voltammograms of His-rGO/ glassy carbon working electrode (GCE) in an inert N2 saturated electrolyte are demonstrated by Fig. 13d, indicating that the products are present after electrolysis without peak currents, suggesting that the source of the products is CO2 blown into solution and not a carbon source for the electrocatalyst. On the other hand, after electrolysis in CO2 saturated electrolyte, Pt@His-rGO/GCE yielded a clear product oxidation peak which is fully evident in Fig. 13f. A cyclic voltammogram containing Pt@His-rGO/GCE in a 2.0 mmol L-1 CH3OH solution with a CH3OH oxidation peak of about 0.55 V (vs Ag/AgCl) was also observed. These illustrate that these Pt's play a very important role in the reduction of CO2 to CH3OH by providing the required hydrogen radicals. Overall, graphene-based metal SACs have gradually become one of the most popular catalysts for the reduction of CO2 through a large number of research advances in recent years, and it has been extensively studied. No matter from the selection and comparison of different metals, the study of catalyst stability, the analysis of CO2 reduction pathways and possible intermediates, all of them reflect their importance. However, for graphene SACs themselves, there are still a lot of places that can be explored and improved in the future, which are worth to be studied for a more environmentally friendly and convenient conversion of CO2. 4 Graphene carbon nanotubes load metal single-cluster catalysts for CO2RR Graphene is highly amenable to aggregation and agglomeration due to its high surface energy and nanoscale thickness. However, SACs often contain mixed structures and coordination in different environments due to the challenges of accurate synthesis, which limits the systematic exploration of CO2RR using SACs and hinders the development of catalysts with high performance CO2RR. To improve the molecular level understanding of CO2RR, models with well-defined structures of SACs are needed. But during chemical reactions, single-atom species' instability causes them to aggregate into clusters or nanoparticles, which restricts their usefulness [152,153]. Therefore, by affixing SACs with precise structures to CNTs, we can contemplate transforming them into SCCs with improved electronic structure stability. A two-step method was developed by Liu et al. [154] to create model SACs with exact structures. Including the construction of explicitly defined SACs centers of molecules Nickel-tetra(amino)phthalocyanine ((Ni-TAPc) [155,156] and attached to conducting carbon carriers CNTs [157-160]. For this purpose, three different methods were investigated to attach Ni-TAPc to CNTs. Namely, Ni-CNT-PP, Ni-CNT-CONH, and Ni-CNT-CC (Fig. 14a ). After extensive studies, it was concluded that the activity, selectivity, and stability of Ni-CNT-CC were optimal for performing CO2RR. Meanwhile, Ni-TAPc/CNT extremely effective interfacial charge transfer was the primary cause of its notable increases in catalytic activity and selectivity. This is because graphene and CNTs, with their exceptional stability, extremely high conductivity and surface area, and capacity to modulate dopant heteroatoms (N, S, and B, etc.), have a strong ability to dope them into the graphite network [56,161-163]. As early as 2018, Zhang et al. [164] proposed a hierarchical atomic Fe-carbon material: encapsulated Fe3C nanocrystals (Fe-N-G/bC) made of Fe atoms with iron atoms scattered in NG nanosheets with N-doped bamboo-CNTs (bC). It was obtained by electrochemical oxidation of graphene films in FeCl4 −-based ionic liquid, followed by thermal annealing (Fig. 14b). N-doped bC can prevent graphene aggregation and improve the surface area. Meanwhile, Fe is very stably co-doped with N in the layered carbon matrix to obtain active Fe atoms for CO2RR with an overpotential of 0.55 V and a maximal CO faradaic efficiency of ∼95 % and lasts for more than 12 h. Highly efficient catalysis with high selectivity and stability is due to the possession of powerful catalytically active sites, and the basis of everything comes from the mutual coordination of Fe and N atoms in a hierarchical porous carbon matrix with easy reactant accessibility and fast electron/mass transport paths, which results in a stable and highly selective reduction of CO2 to CO. Graphene and carbon nanotubes are the most widely used carriers for electrochemical reactions. Although conventional graphene-based metal and nitrogen co-doped carbon (M-N/C) can provide dense M-Nx sites throughout the carbon layer, the electrochemically active region at the gas/solid/liquid three-phase interface is usually insufficient because two-dimensional (2D) ultrathin graphene nanosheets are susceptible to stacking due to the interactions between strong π-π intercalations [165]. The use of carbon nanotubes can provide highly porous networks that allow for efficient mass transfer [166,167]. The key drawback, however, is that the available low-density M-Nx sites because only M-Nx anchored to the outermost walls are thought to be able to reach the reactants, while M-Nx confined to the carbon nanotube the inner wall is inaccessible to the reaction. Thus, there is a considerable need in developing facile, cost-effective, and scalable approaches to fabricate M-N/C with favorable carbon architecture decorated with atomically dispersed M−Nx sites to enable high-efficiency CO2 reduction. To this end, Pan et al. [168] investigated and fabricated Fe-N4 sites hierarchical CNT with graphene nanoribbon (GNR) network (Fe-N/CNT@GNR-x, x is the KMnO4: CNT mass ratio) with different GNR contents after oxidation of the CNT tube lubricant with added potassium permanganate followed by urea calcination (Fig. 14c, d, e). After varying the amount of KMnO4, the CNT was decomposed into CNT@GNR and finally GNR. it was found that Fe-N/CNT@GNR-2 has four positions to host the isolated Fe-N4 site: the CNT, GNR bulk, GNR armchair edge, and GNR zigzag edge. Upon comparison, it was found that CNT and zigzag sites promoted CO2 activation and intermediate *COOH formation, and zigzag edges and armchair edges weakened *CO adsorption and promoted *CO desorption. It is concluded that Fe-N/CNT@GNR-2 provides excellent performance for CO2RR, which stems from its considerable active area and sufficient mass transfer. In conclusion, SCCs are one of the most concerned functional catalytic systems. The precise preparation of SCCs at the atomic level enables the precise tuning of their geometrical and electronic structures, thus optimizing their catalytic performance. In addition, the systematic study of cluster catalysis contributes to the understanding of the catalytic principles in the transformation of substances on a large scale. Therefore, the stable preparation and characterization of SCCs, as well as the exploration of the microscopic catalytic mechanism, are the core of present and future development. 5 Conclusions Electrochemical graphene SACs/SCCs is one of the effective methods for the treatment and conversion of CO2. The principles of CO2RR are briefly explained, the intermediates potential products that may be produced during the reaction are analyzed in detail. Meanwhile, the overview of defect and modified graphene SACs and SCCs are widely discussed with emphasis TMs (Ni, Cu, Fe, Zn, Ag, Ru, Pt) on SACs (such as those made of NG), which are common catalysts for CO2RR. Through the CO2RR pathway and free energy analysis, it is concluded that the final products produced by graphene (N-doped or defective) and TMs affect the CO2 reduction efficiency. For SCCs, CO2RR via carbon nanotubes also has the same advantages with high stability and fast reaction speed. Graphene exhibits high malleability for CO2RR, especially with various atoms adoption to form combination. Further exploration of different metal single-atoms doped graphene for CO2RR is needed. For SCCs, there are still ample research opportunities to explore a wider for improving the activity and selectivity of CO2 conversion. Therefore, explorations of graphene SACs/SCCs are warranted in order to identify environmentally friendly and efficient CO2 conversion paths in future. coredata.dc:description: Due to the increasing concentration of carbon dioxide (CO2) in the atmosphere, the conversion of CO2 into usable products is particularly important. The electrochemical reduction reaction of CO2 (CO2RR) has got great attentions on single-atom catalysts (SACs) and single-cluster catalysts (SCCs) in recent years. In general, graphene is widely applied in CO2RR because of its excellent stability, predominant electrical conductivity and favorable electrochemical properties. In this review, we have summarized the electrochemical CO2RR by various graphene SACs/SCCs such as nitrogen-doped graphene, defect graphene, defect modified graphene and carbon nanotubes. Additionally, the reaction mechanisms for CO2RR and the pathways to diverse products are discussed in details. Finally, the potential opportunities and prospects of utilizing graphene SACs/SCCs for CO2RR are presented.
